comments.commentBody:
Get real censor, the Republican stance on gay marriage doesn't just trash gay people, it makes every childless heterosexual couple second class too.

The secular societal interest to promote marriage is first and foremost as a vow of sexual fidelity that reduces the spread of veneral disease and improves public mental health.

Augustine 25 -- If you don't like mandates, you must be against Scott Brown.

He supports the Massachusetts Health Insurance Reform that has mandates.

I have the distinct impression that you're a socialist.
This repeal pledge for the GnOP House caucus is from the Club For Growth, the right-wing lunatic fringe group who basically opposes anything involving progress.

How about some clear reporting about "grassroots" movements vs. "astroturf," and who is funding this spontaneous, genuine, teabagger movement?

C'mon, NYTimes, do your job. Not two years after it all blows up, but now, as it's happening.

Yes, we must retain these geniuses with fat bonuses.

Or heck, they'll go to another sector of the economy.

And screw that one up with game theory and differential equations.

Guarantee: The GOP -- who hated the bail outs -- will vote in lockstep against taxes to pay it back.

One would think with Mr. Bush gone after one year (the world thought Bush was the bad guy) and the good guy, President Obama, that we would see a change for the good...diplomacy, serious talks with world leaders and less American political dominance of others.

It did not happen.

President Obama has increased dramatically the unmanned drones over Pakistan...used military helicopters in parts of Africa attacking insurgents...increased troop levels in Afghanistan: All in the name of our national interest.

It has been documented in the latest threats and actual terrorist happenings in our country...Maj. Hasan and the Negerian underwear bomber...that they were related to the directives of President Obama.

President Obama with seemingly good intentions...is playing right into the hands of Osama bin Laden...radicalizing some in the Muslim world, to do us harm...amazingly without the help of George W. Bush.

Augustine is now whining over what he calls Obama's predictions. I am still waiting, after nearly eight years, for Bush's promise and prediction that WMD's will be found in Iraq. And that one cost 4372 American lives.

The president wants us to believe that his secret deal with big pharma was done for us, rather than his campaign war chest, and wants us to believe the AMA (who can count less than 20% of american doctors as members) loves this bill by trotting out some doctors with white coats slapped on them by white house operatives, and wants us to believe that my accountant knows less than the congressional budget folks when he tells me I can't balance 6 years of high expenses by using 10 years of income.

Even democrats know this is smoke and mirrors, with the real winners being the unions and fans of washington bureaucracy. The czar or 'secretary' will have 18 months to tell us what a 'qualified plan' is, how much we'll have to pay for it, and what IRS form to fill out if we neither qualify for welfare or refuse to pay $12,000 for a policy. Young people who campaigned for the president will get an entry level job and find out that they will be required by law to subsidize the insurance policies of baby boomers, who use 5 times more services but will be paying no more than twice the premium of a 20 year old. If their employer happens to be located in a high cost area and gives them a policy, he'll be taxed a whopping 40% of it's cost (unless you are in a union like SEIU).

It's clear who the winners will be, they won't be american citizens, they won't be democrats in the 2010 elections. Fans of a government takeover of 1/5 of the economy that still does not get us an affordable option, that lavishes entitlements on groups that have nothing to do with sickness, and fans of allowing mid-level practitioners the authority to order tests and treatments that today only a Physician can prescribe will cheer, the rest of us, well, we'll be broke.

"Loosen the ties between American technology firms and countries that restrict human rights"? Yea, right. The greatest human rights that the GOP care for is to get themselves elected. This is the same group that has greased the skids for American corporations to ship, forever, millions of jobs overseas to "better compete on the world market" so that consumers can pay less for the stuff they buy, irrespective of the true costs to that tax paying consumer. Let's be fair, plenty of Democrats have also enabled corporations to "raise their productivity" by going to the lowest bidder in countries that don't even begin to have what amounts to a level playing field. Playing by the rules between trading nations might be nice, but I can't even say we have that.

I applaud Google's initial actions and I do hope they follow through and say no to the Chinese government. From my perspective, I see a lose, lose situation in dealings with the Chinese government in context of the current situation. My hope that the Chinese people will affect change, not from any altruistic or noble reasons, but in the expectation that they will be exposed to the internet and with the expansion of their consumer society, they will also become fat and lazy as so many others have before them.

To Auggie-

You keep bringing up the fact that your wife is unemployed--since March of last year.

I don't know a single economist who disputes that the Great Recession began 15 months before that--and 13 months BEFORE Obama even announced he was running for President.

Yet you still seem to blame him for something that occurred three months into his presidency?

And by that measure--9/11 was not Bush's responsibilty?

As for the "financial stress" on your family?

Cry me a river.

On another thread, you're gushing about Opryland--and saying if you can book another gig or two there--you'll be springing for tickets to the Teabagger Ball--at $600 a ticket.

Sorry Aug--but in a nation where the "staycation" has become the norm--if you've got a couple of grand to spend buying your way into an event populated by misinformed and frightened, aging white people--you shouldn't be complaining.

I heard on Tom Ashbrook's radio program yesterday two teabaggers being interviewed and taking phone calls. At the end, one of the teabaggers stated that they have the option of "four boxes". The first, the soap box, second, the ballot box, third, the check off box on your tax form. And the last box, he stated, was the bullet box!! Yeow!! That's right, folks. It's going to be a circus. And with "I can see it from my porch" Sarah leading the fray, it will be much more entertaining that the Tonight Show jokefest. I can't wait.

I believe that it will be the GOP that will be harrased by this group. The American Taliban will nationalize the NY 23rd district mentality. The sensible folks of the GOP will be run out by this group. These guys should be prepared to have a long journey through the political desert. Take lots of tea with you, you're going to need it.

Well, it looks like these guys won't get all that many votes on the Upper West Side, Ann Arbor and Chicago.   But if you don't think something is going on in the rest of the country you're kidding yourselves.

O seems to think the Democrats will be running on the health care bill. I'd bet a lot that they'll run as far away from that as possible, and base their campaign on the fact that they're not G. W. Bush.  I'm also guessing they'll see a bloodbath of epic proportions.
Why is it the responsibility of people making over $500,000 to pay for health insurance for other people?  I liked most of your arguement but think the last part doesn't make sense at all.

This shady, back door politicking is exactly the reason that this bill shouldn't be passed at all. When you have to accomodate unions in an unconstitutional way to get it passed and then rely on the supreme court to overturn it, it is a BAD BILL.

Throw it out and start over!

I can't believe it. Congress has designed a healthcare reform package that will successfuly eliminate the middle class. My husband and I are in our 50s. I pay more out of pocket on premiums and deductibles on my employer sponsored healthcare plan because of the higher age demographics of the workers in the non-profit agency I work for. We get terrible health coverage and pay higher amounts on monthly premiums and have high deductibles. Our yearly income is less than $45,000 a year. Now, it sounds like we are going to pay even more for healthcare only to get even crappier healthcare coverage. My husband is uninsured because we could not afford to put him on my healthcare plan (it would cost almost as much as my mortgage payment to put him on my plan. My mortgage payment takes half of my monthly paycheck.)  I foresee having to sell my house because I will have to buy healthcare coverage for my husband. If I don't purchase coverage for him, we will be fined $750 the first year with fine amounts increasing exorbitantly following years. This version of the healthcare bill is absolutely terrible. I have been a Democrat all of my adult life. I expected that the Democratic party would have fought for Medicare for all and taxed the rich to pay for the healthcare reform or considered a VAT to pay for a single payer healthcare program. Insurers will be taxed 40% on high cost insurnace policues. The insurance companies will of course pass that cost on to us. This inevitably means higher premiums, deductibles and poorer healthcare coverage. The middle class will lose and the insurance companies will win.

The government is in health care. The government runs Medicare and Medicaid. So when you become 65, you will need to decline Medicare and then you can purchase your own policy for 20 or 30 Thousand dollars a year.
Be sure to make a pact not to sign up.

Why not have an FDIC-style system for doctors? Have all doctors pay into the same pool? A medical board along with legal experts can weed out frivolous suits. If a doctor makes an honest mistake, the patient can be paid reasonable damages from the "pool". If the doctor is negligent a pre-determined number of times, he becomes a Physician's Assistant -it would be a shame to totally waste their education.
Just look at how many folks around these parts disguise their identity.

The phenomenon of meanness in anonymous posts, not to mention the hateful screeds that plague things like YouTube vids, have always made me wonder whether people do these things because there is a deficit of honesty in everyday conversation and they are overcompensating for the lack of truthful feeling in their everyday interactions.  People who feel to constrained to express their real feelings, for emotional or perceived social reasons, afford themselves a moment of freedom by lashing out.

I agree with the 'anonymity' part; but not the 'drive-by' part. Very often, the same people will visit a forum or discussion board, so 'identities' do begin to resolve and we realize that there are 'real people' on the other end. But you still have some distance. I find that I (sadly) am much more likely to respond more forcefully on a board like this, than in real life (although I hope I don't initiate such exchanges. If I do, I apologize.)

The same kind of behavior occurs amongst drivers. If one could easily look up a license plate and connect it to a person, don't you think 'hand gestures' and more egregious 'private enforcement' behaviors (like slamming on one's brakes, swerving into a lane, etc.) would be greatly diminished? I'm not suggesting that, of course, because then we'd have even more serious altercations at people's homes.

Two other comments:

1. I often respond in kind, because it bothers me when I see something that is open to such a wide audience (essentially the world), that is racist, sexist, 'religion-ist,' not factual, etc. Someone posted above about the correlation between the inept grammar, punctuation, spelling, etc. and the usually bankrupt content of the post. I too have found that correlation, and often use that as the starting point to raking the poster over the coals. Sadly, someone who attacked me on another Times blog got that treatment the other day.

2. I also find that once a certain threshold number of participants is crossed, things inevitably go downhill. I spent years on a site with a fairly narrow scope of interest. It was fantastic. I don't think there were any nasty exchanges for several years. But as the site grew in popularity, that familial spirit evaporated.

How can there be an ETF from Google?  Customers aren't contracting for service with them, are they?  If T-Mobile decides to subsidize the phone with a contract, then they are entitled to impose an ETF.

Yes, most of us have been nasty online, and most of us have corrected that behavior. But anonymity brings the emotionally-damaged and angry out of their closet. I do believe they enjoy acting the way they do online, precisely because they think what they're doing can't be traced to them (I'm surprised more of them don't realize that it often can). Communal censure prevents them from behaving this way in real life, but online they can just change their account, their IP address, and move onto another forum.

And yet I've seen cultures created online that don't tolerate troll behavior.
How widespread is the problem of internet snottiness around the globe? Is it just the English-speaking world, or do such traditionally polite people as Thais get nasty on the Net, too?
